p: The mean of the relative abundance of chemical classes was distributed as follows (Figure 5, Supplementary Table 2): OM (71.2%), OS (13.7%), SH (6.1%), NT (4.9%), MH (3.2%), and AC (0.3%). A different distribution was recorded by Pistelli et al. ( 2017) in L. angustifolia ‘Maillette’, where the amount of OS and SH were lower than that observed in this study (0.5 and 1.8%, respectively). Commonly, monoterpenes represent the major class in the oil of Lavandula species (Lis-Balchin, 2003) and our data are consistent with values reviewed by Prusinowska and Smigielski ( 2014). In this study, significant positive linear regression fitted between MH and NT concentration with latitude (Figures 6A,B) and AC content with altitude (Figure 6D); instead, a negative linear regression fitted between SH and latitude (Figure 6C), an opposite behavior than that observed in Teucrium polium EO by Sadeghi et al. ( 2014).
